Award.AbstractNarration:
Analysis of operators and inherent phenomena of noncommutativity have been developing in response to refinement of physical models of the world as well as to advancement of other sciences and technology. This project is devoted to open problems in operator theory that arise in mathematical physics, noncommutative analysis and geometry, and the theory of single-variable and multivariate operator functions. The project is also designed to strengthen connections between several areas of mathematics, contribute to general education, and enhance student research.

The proposed topics include establishing properties of operator functions with noncommuting arguments that are similar to classical properties of the respective scalar functions, understanding the impact of perturbations on spectral subspaces of operators, and studying the structure of elements belonging to operator algebras. The essence of the proposed research consists in developing innovative methods for handling different effects of noncommutativity that appear in the problems, and beyond. Such methods are expected to emerge from subtle synthesis of various techniques in analysis and operator theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project was dedicated to solving open problems in operator theory and developing respective noncommutative analysis methods via subtle synthesis of various techniques in analysis. The obtained results include advancements on multilinear Schur multipliers and their generalizations to the continuous infinite-dimensional setting, which are called multiple operator integrals; approximation of operator functions; perturbation problems and trace formulas for differential operators, in particular, operators arising in noncommutative geometry; positivity preserving properties of trace functionals; nonlinear inverse perturbation problems. The PI published six papers in peer refereed journals and submitted two papers for publication.

The project has also contributed to education and training of students and a postdoc. The postdoc coauthored a paper on one of the grant projects; one PhD student defended a dissertation and published a research paper; another PhD student has a research paper in preparation; an undergraduate student defended an honors thesis. The PI has (co)organized a departmental colloquium and analysis seminar. The PI has given numerous conferences and colloquium talks; the students supervised by the PI have given seminar talks on their research as well as made educational presentations to school students and teachers. The PI's mentees either started/continued their careers in academic institutions or are going to earn a graduate degree in science.
